paragraphs.text:
%md # **Economics** by Anish Singh blog site: [Zeppelin Notes](https://zeppelinnotes.blogspot.com) ![Image](http://slc.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/pictures/pageBackground/EconGlopeBlue_0.jpg) ## Introduction **Economics** is a notebook that attempts to throw light on some of the economic issues of the world by analyzing the present situation and the factors affecting
them. Two of the most recent issues have been taken up, they are : the African Growth Story and Latin America and Paraguay. Analysis for each of these issues can be
broadly divided into two parts, the first part is on the description of the situation itself while the second half is on the analysis of the factors that affect
that situation. Data for all of these subjects(or issues) has been taken from the International Monetary Fund which provides a varied list of indicators to choose
from. To decide which indicators are relevant for a particular situation, certain blogs, publications and research papers have been referred, links to which have
been provided at appropriate places. A detailed description of the process of choosing the indicators has been put up on the blog site mentioned above.
This notebook uses Apache Spark for analysis of data, the visualization capabilities of Apache Zeppelin and custom visualizations using the D3 library and Helium application.

Economics

by Anish Singh
blog site: Zeppelin Notes

Introduction

Economics is a notebook that attempts to throw light on some of the economic issues of the world by analyzing the present situation and the factors affecting

them. Two of the most recent issues have been taken up, they are : the African Growth Story and Latin America and Paraguay. Analysis for each of these issues can be

broadly divided into two parts, the first part is on the description of the situation itself while the second half is on the analysis of the factors that affect

that situation. Data for all of these subjects(or issues) has been taken from the International Monetary Fund which provides a varied list of indicators to choose

from. To decide which indicators are relevant for a particular situation, certain blogs, publications and research papers have been referred, links to which have

been provided at appropriate places. A detailed description of the process of choosing the indicators has been put up on the blog site mentioned above.



This notebook uses Apache Spark for analysis of data, the visualization capabilities of Apache Zeppelin and custom visualizations using the D3 library and Helium application.

paragraphs.text:
%md ## 1. The African Growth Story ![Image](https://media.licdn.com/mpr/mpr/shrinknp_400_400/p/3/005/0a6/092/07bc44e.jpg) The first economic issue to be taken up is the [growth story of Africa](http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/survey/so/2016/CAR052616A.htm). After an unprecedented growth for the last ten years, which showed a positive growing picture of the

Sub-Saharan Africa, the outlook for the region is dimming. It has suffered a steep slump in growth owing to the softer global economic conditions. Natural resource

producers, especially South Africa, Democratic Republic of Congo and Nigeria have been adversely affected. This section of the notebook aims to analyse the growth

situation in Africa and the factors that have been affecting it.
The following abbreviations and country codes have been used in this analysis: 1. MG = Madagascar 2. MU = Mauritius 3. NG = Nigeria 4. CF = Central African Republic 5. CD = Democratic Republic of Congo 6. ZA = South Africa

Sub-Saharan Africa, the outlook for the region is dimming. It has suffered a steep slump in growth owing to the softer global economic conditions. Natural resource

producers, especially South Africa, Democratic Republic of Congo and Nigeria have been adversely affected. This section of the notebook aims to analyse the growth

situation in Africa and the factors that have been affecting it.



The following abbreviations and country codes have been used in this analysis:

  1. MG = Madagascar
  2. MU = Mauritius
  3. NG = Nigeria
  4. CF = Central African Republic
  5. CD = Democratic Republic of Congo
  6. ZA = South Africa

paragraphs.text:
%md #### i. Broad Money and Revenue We shall begin by examining the variation in the broad money and revenue of the countries chosen to represent the region and graphs have been generated for both of
the indicators below.
**Broad Money** may be roughly defined as the total amount of money held by the country in all forms of assets. In the graph on the left, the broad money for the
various regions has been compared. We see that it remains nearly constant for all the nations in the recent years and there are slight differences among the
nations themselves with Mauritius leading the other nations, followed by South Africa and the bottom most in the graph is Congo.
Shown on the right is the graph for the **revenues** of the regions, in which South Africa and Mauritius just exchange their places and South Africa has the
greatest revenues for all the years. An important observation from the graph is the revenue slump of Nigeria which had been as good as South Africa in 2004 but fell
steeply from 2011 to 2016. Revenues for other nations remain nearly constant. Congo overtook Nigeria in the net revenues in the year 2012, however Congo still lags
behind in the amount of Broad Money held by the nation. These graphs also include the data for the year 2017 as projected by the International Monetary Fund.

%md #### ii. Current Account(% of GDP) **Current Account** is defined as the sum of the amount of money received from the balance of trade(exports - imports), net income from abroad and the net curr
-ent transfers and is an important indicator of the health of the nation. Shown below(on the left) is the scatter plot for the Current Account(expressed as % of
GDP).The highest point for all the years has been that of Nigeria for the year 2005, which has declined thereafter. Unfortunately, the current account percentage
for all the nations representing the region has been fairly low for all the years( on or below 0%). This depicts the slow growth in the region.
In the paragraph on the right, we perforn clustering on the current account dataset, to get an idea about how the nations will be performing in the years to come.
For a choice of four clusters, we get the cluster centers as shown below and accordingly group the nations based on the projections contained in the datasets. We
get the four gropus shown in the result and after using the clustering model for prediction, we find that *none of the nations* will have moderate or good current
account percentages for the years to come, they will either be low or very low (scroll result on the right).

paragraphs.text:
%sql
select country, value, year from CurrtData where year between '2004' and '2015'

//from the Currt Account dataSet select only the values till 2015 and perform clustering
import org.apache.spark.mllib.linalg.Vectors
import org.apache.spark.mllib.clustering.{KMeans, KMeansModel}

val currtFrame = sqlContext.sql("SELECT value from CurrtData where (year between '2004' and '2015')")   //get the values for the required years
val currtVec = currtFrame.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)).cache()        //get the rdd of Vectors for the values

val clusters = KMeans.train(currtVec, 4, 20)            //perform clustering on the data to get the clusters

println("Based on the clusters derived from the KMeans model, we can classify the regions in terms of the Current Account holdings into the following groups, whose cluster centers are displayed alongside :- ")
println("Very Low : \t " + clusters.clusterCenters(2))
println("Low :      \t " + clusters.clusterCenters(0))
println("Moderate : \t " + clusters.clusterCenters(3))
println("Good :     \t " + clusters.clusterCenters(1))

println("Lets find out how will the region be in the next years... \n")

//South Africa
val SAfrica = sqlContext.sql("SELECT value from CurrtData where (year between '2016' and '2017') and country = 'ZA'")
val SAVec   = SAfrica.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)) 
val SAPred  = clusters.predict(SAVec)
println("The cluster to which South Africa will belong are : ")
SAPred.take(2).foreach(println)
println("South Africa will still be in the low group in the next two years. \n")

//Nigeria
val Nigeria = sqlContext.sql("SELECT value from CurrtData where (year between '2016' and '2017') and country = 'NG'")
val NigerVec = Nigeria.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)) 
val NigPred = clusters.predict(NigerVec)
println("The cluster to which Nigeria will belong are : ")
NigPred.take(2).foreach(println)
println("Nigeria will also be in the low group in the next two years.\n")

//Congo
val Congo = sqlContext.sql("SELECT value from CurrtData where (year between '2016' and '2017') and country = 'CD'")
val ConVec = Congo.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)) 
val ConPred = clusters.predict(ConVec)
println("The cluster to which Congo will belong are : ")
ConPred.take(2).foreach(println)
println("Democratic Republic of Congo will be in the very low group.\n")

//Central African Republic
val CARep = sqlContext.sql("SELECT value from CurrtData where (year between '2016' and '2017') and country = 'CF'")
val CARepVec = CARep.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)) 
val CARepPred = clusters.predict(CARepVec)
println("The cluster to which Central African Republic will belong are : ")
CARepPred.take(2).foreach(println)
println("Central African Republic will also be in the very low group.\n")

//Mauritius
val Maurit = sqlContext.sql("SELECT value from CurrtData where (year between '2016' and '2017') and country = 'MU'")
val MauVec = Maurit.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble))
val MauPred = clusters.predict(MauVec)
println("The cluster to which Mauritius will belong are : ")
MauPred.take(2).foreach(println)
println("Mauritius will be in the low group for the coming years.\n")

//Madagascar
val Madag = sqlContext.sql("SELECT value from CurrtData where (year between '2016' and '2017') and country = 'MG'")
val MadVec = Madag.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble))
val MadPred = clusters.predict(MadVec)
println("The cluster to which Madagascar will belong are : ")
MadPred.take(2).foreach(println)
println("Madagascar also will be in the low group in the years to follow.")

paragraphs.text:
%md #### iii. Gross National Savings **Gross National Savings** may be defined as the savings of a nation after all the consumption has been accounted for(Gross National Income - Total Consumption).
National Savings may be indicative of the extent to which a nation has its expenditure under control. In the graph below(on the let), we compare the National
Savings against the Total Expenditure values for the nations for all of the previous years. From the plot, we can deduce that Nigeria shows an almost linear
correlation between the two values and also gives the peak value for Savings as it has moderate expenditures. On the other hand, the regions having high
expenditures such as South Africa and Mauritius have moderate Savings. Other nations fall in between these two extremes and have low expenditures and savings.
On the right side(below), we have the bar chart of Revenues less Total Expenditures to give us another complete picture for the savings of the governments of the
various nations. This chart coincides with the the one on the left, showing Nigeria to be the only country with positive savings when calculated this way. All the
other nations do not show positive savings for this chart, they are unable to control their expenditures. Even Nigeria had positive savings for the initial years
when the revenues for the nation were high. As the revenues declined, the savings also got diminished and turned negative after 2009.

%md #### iv. Gross Debt Position According to the International Monetary Fund, the **Gross External Debt** is the amount, at any point in time, of disbursed or contractual liabilities of the
residents of a country to non residents to repay principal, with or without interest, or to pay interest, with or without principal. In simpler terms, it refers
to the amount of money owed in debt by a nation to its lenders. The pie charts below show the debts for the representative regions for some of the years of the
last decade. In 2005, the greatest debts were that of Congo and the Central African Republic and the least was that of Nigeria. This pie chart is well explained
by the revenues graph above which has the both the high debt nations on the bottom most position while Nigeria had the maximum revenues back then. This scenario
changed over time to give the pie charts in the succeding paragraphs where the Gross Debt of South Africa and Mauritius increased noticeably and that of Congo got
reduced. One good point is that inspite of falling revenues Nigeria has been able to curb its national debt and keep it under control.

%md #### v. Gross Capital Formation **Gross Capital Formation** consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Shown below(on the
left) is a graph of the Gross Capital Formation for the representative nations. We can clearly see that Madagascar and Mauritius have been the leading nations in
all of the recent years. This implies that infrastructural and other asset development has been the maximum in these nations, while it has been the least for the
Central African Republic and Congo. Development in South Africa and Nigeria has been fairly constant for the recent years. Considering the debt data above, due
to consistently high spending Mauritius and Madagascar might have had high debts while Congo and Central African Republic also have high debts inspite of having
low capital formation. This may be due to organizational inefficiencies in the latter two regions. South Africa's debt is also well explained by the spending on
Capital Formation.
The paragraph on the right side(below) performs correlation between the capital formation and debt position values for the nations and we get to see that they
are positively correlated with a correlation coefficient of 0.386. So the debt position can to some extent be explained on the basis of the capital formation
spending. More spending combined with the inability to generate adequate revenues causes debt.

paragraphs.text:
%md All the factors examined above indicate that the growth in the region(as represented by the chosen nations) has been constant over time(fairly slow);
the gross debt has increased proportionately for the countries without a great increase in the capital formation values. Some nations such as Nigeria have had a
staggering drop in revenues which might have adversely affected the growth. Net Savings as calculated from the revenue less expenditures graph shows that all of
the nations have debt not savings. The current account position will also be low for the nations as calculated in one of the paragraph above.
### Analysis of the Factors affecting Growth We shall now examine the factors that have been responsible for the slow growth in the region.
#### i. Consumer Price Index **Consumer Price Indexes** (CPIs) are index numbers that measure changes in the prices of goods and services purchased or otherwise acquired by households, which
households use directly, or indirectly, to satisfy their own needs and wants. CPIs are widely used to index pensions and social security benefits. They are also
used as a proxy for the general rate of inflation and are used to compare the purchasing power parities. In the graph shown below(on the left), we can clearly see
that the CPI has only been rising for the region, which is an indication of the inflation in commodity prices. This is justified by the drought that struck the
region in the recent years. The CPI reached an all time high for the year 2012 and has stayed fairly contant since then.
To the right we have a plot of the Gross Debt of the region compared against the consumer price indices and we get to see a linear correlation between the two
quantities. The gross debt has been increasing constantly but becomes somewhat constant towards the right of the graph, since we have seen that the CPI for the
region is on the rise, we can say that the debt would be difficult to control unless there is an increase in the revenues, leading to tougher economic conditions
for the region.

%md #### ii. Access To Financial Services **Access To Financial Services** is an economic parameter defined by the IMF which indicates the extent to which a nation(region) is equiped with financial services
and it collects data on various financial institutions for this purpose. As a measure of the access to financial services, here we shall consider the number of
Bank Branches in the region and compare the number of branches with their usage to get an idea about this parameter. Shown Below is a bar chart of the number of
bank branches which presents the disparities in the access to financial services in the region. Nigeria leads the other regions by a large margin followed by South
Africa and the other nations come no where close the leading nations, thereby indicating the poor availability of the financial services in the under-developed
nations of the region. Some nations such as the Central African Republic had a total of 8 branches in 2007, 9 in 2008 and reached only uptill 22 branches in 2013.
In the columns below the graphs, we find the nations that have above mean broad money for all of the years. Only two nations make it to the list, South Africa
and Mauritius. Surprisingly, Nigeria that has the highest number of bank branches and bank usage does not have above mean broad money for any of the years. This is
well explained because Nigeria has less debt, expenditure under control and maximum savings, so it can afford to have high financial activity inspite of having less
broad money. While the other nations, South Africa and Mauritius have more expenditure, more debt and low savings therefore to keep these factors under control, the
region has less financial activity.

%md #### iii. Value Of Exports The next factor that we shall examine is the net **value of exports** (excluding taxes), to get an idea about how well the region is able to sell its goods and
services to the rest of the world. Shown below(on the left) is a graph which reveals that Nigeria and South Africa are much ahead of the other nations in terms of
the exports and that the value of their exports has been rising consistently; on the other hand, the other nations of the region don't even come close to these
leading nations in terms of the value of exports although Madagascar is slightly better off and shows the same growth patterns as Nigeria and South Africa. This
is indicaive of the low net value of exports in the region, especially in the recent years due natural calamities like drought that have caused tough times for
natural resource producers.
As an evidence of the low net value of exports, we plot a graph(on the right) of the current account values against the values of exports. The current account
holding of a nation is the sum of the balance of trade plus the net income from abroad, therefore by definition the value of exports play a crucial role in accounting
for the net current account of a country. However, in the plot below, the current account values tend to stay constant with the increasing exports indicating that the
net imports are almost equal to or exceed the value of exports. This is a grim situation because the exports are largely insufficient and incapable of causing any
dramatic boost in the current account holding of the region.

%md #### iv. Expenditure of Government The last factor that we shall examine is the Government Expenditure classified by its function. Here we shall consider only two functions of Government, one being
the net expenditure and the other being the expenditure on fuel and energy. Data for only three of the representative nations have been plotted below(as provided by
the IMF). South Africa and Mauritius have high government expenditures with sharp increases between 2008 and 2013 whereas Madagascar has had more of expenditure on
fuel and energy. Net Expenditure for the government of Madagascar fell steeply between 2008 and 2009 as is also reflected in the fuel and energy graph. The government

expenditures of the nations rise at a time when their net revenues were also rising. Although the increasing revenues weren't sufficient to pull the nations out of
debt which increased for South Africa in the recent years.
In the paragraphs below the graphs, we calculate the weight of the net government expenditure as it affects the total expenditure of the region by performing linear

regression between the two values and get a high positive values for the weight. This is also evident in the plot drawn alongside, which shows a straight linear
correlation between the two values. The expected results indicate that the total expenditures are largely dominated by the government expenditures as the government

controls nearly all of the sectors, so to keep the expenditures under control, the government must have its own expenditures under control. Further, this indicates
that the government policies are largely responsible for the debt cicumstances arising in the nations.

paragraphs.title: Expenditure on Fuel and Energy
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select * from FEExpen

//perform regression between the total expenditure values and the net govt expenditure to get the weight of net govt expenditure
import org.apache.spark.mllib.linalg.Vectors
import org.apache.spark.mllib.regression.LabeledPoint
import org.apache.spark.mllib.regression.{LinearRegressionWithSGD, LinearRegressionModel}

val ordExp = expenData.filter($"country".isin("ZA","MU","MG") && $"year" < 2014).orderBy("country","year").select("value")
val ordNge = ngeData.orderBy("country", "year").select("value")

val expValues = ordExp.map(row => row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)                             //get the values corresponding to the total expenditure
val ngeValues = ordNge.map(row => Vectors.dense(row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble))              //get the net Govt expenditure values

val expNge = expValues.zip(ngeValues)
val trainingSet = expNge.map(ele => LabeledPoint(ele._1, ele._2)).cache()

val model = LinearRegressionWithSGD.train(trainingSet, 65)                                          //train a linear regression model to get the weights

//get the weight values of the net govt expenditures
println("The weight of the feature is : " +  model.weights)

%md In the analysis presented above, we have been able to see the complete scenario of the African region's economy and the factors that have been affecting
it. In the face of low current account values, constant(non increasing) revenues and low value of exports, the goverment policies will be largely responsible
for the expenses to be borne out. As suggested by the IMF, a change of fiscal and government policies may just help the region put itself back on the track of
progress although growth will be slow for the next few years.
## 2. Latin America and Paraguay ![Image](http://fm.cnbc.com/applications/cnbc.com/resources/img/editorial/2014/07/17/101844217-80291294.530x298.jpg?v=1405603939) The next issue to be examined is the economic condition of [Latin America and Paraguay](http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/survey/so/2016/car060116a.htm).
Paraguay has been mentioned separately because it stands out in terms of economic growth and development even as the other nations of the region face
tough conditions and recession. We shall have a look at the economic factors that affect the region and how Paraguay has been able to cope with it.
The following abbreviations have been used in the analysis below: 1. BR = Brazil 2. AR = Argentina 3. UY = Uruguay 4. PY = Paraguay 5. BO = Bolivia

result.msg:
In the analysis presented above, we have been able to see the complete scenario of the African region's economy and the factors that have been affecting

it. In the face of low current account values, constant(non increasing) revenues and low value of exports, the goverment policies will be largely responsible

for the expenses to be borne out. As suggested by the IMF, a change of fiscal and government policies may just help the region put itself back on the track of

progress although growth will be slow for the next few years.


2. Latin America and Paraguay

The next issue to be examined is the economic condition of Latin America and Paraguay.

Paraguay has been mentioned separately because it stands out in terms of economic growth and development even as the other nations of the region face

tough conditions and recession. We shall have a look at the economic factors that affect the region and how Paraguay has been able to cope with it.



The following abbreviations have been used in the analysis below:

  1. BR = Brazil
  2. AR = Argentina
  3. UY = Uruguay
  4. PY = Paraguay
  5. BO = Bolivia

paragraphs.text:
%md #### i. Balance Of Payments The **Balance of Payments** of a country is the record of all economic transactions between the residents of a country and the rest of the world over a given
period of time(most commonly over a year). Shown below(to the left) is the line graph of the balance of payments for the Latin America region which presents a
poor picture of the trade in the region. The net balance of payments has been tumbling down (especially evident for Bolivia) for all the nations and has no
prospects of rising in the years to come(even for the projections for the years to come). When expressed as a percent of the GDP, the Balance of Payment values
consistently stand at negative values for all the regions.
#### ii. Gross Debt The **Gross Debt** is simply the stock of outstanding government debt. It is an indicator of how well the nation(region) is able to manage its expenditures and the
inflow of revenues in the region. This graph also shows that the region is not doing economically well as the gross debt for all the nations has been either
constant or slightly increasing and at the same time forms large percentages of GDP. For some nations such as Brazil which is facing recession, it is projected that
the debt may go as high as 91% of GDP.
However, for both of the graphs shown below, Paraguay can easily be distinguished. Although not altogether very good in terms of the balance of Payments with a
negative (still highest) value of -1.835 and simply better than others in terms of the Gross Debt(well under 25% of fiscal year GDP), the nation has been
outperforming the others in the Latin America region. Even the IMF projections for the country indicate that the debt won't increase above 30% for the years to
come. Even as the other nations have been hard hit due to economic inefficiencies and other natural factors, Paraguay has been able to keep itself in good shape.

paragraphs.text:
%md We have been able to see the economic condition of the nations in the Latin America region through some of the important indicators, next we shall take
a look at the factors that have been affecting the region economically.
### Analysis of the factors affecting the Economy We begin with the Net Government Lending and Borrowing for the nations of the region.
#### i. General Government Net Lending/Borrowing The first factor that we shall examine is the net lending and borrowing that the governments of the regions rely on, for economic stability. **Net Lending** is
an economic measure of whether governments are either providing financial resources to other sectors of the economy or using resources from other sectors of the
economy(the latter is known as **Net Borrowing**). In the paragraph on the left(below), we perform correlation between the values of net lending and borrowing of
the goverment and the balance of payments of the nations to get a high correlation coefficient value of 0.6012. If a government feels the need to have more
lending and borrowing with other sectors of the economy to fulfill the economic needs, it will participate in more trade leading to a net increase in the balance
of payments, indicative of more economic activity. As in the case of Bolivia and Paraguay, the Balance of Payments increases linearly with the net lending and
borrowing rate.

paragraphs.title: Balance Of Payments vs. Net Lending/Borrowing
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
select L.value as LendBorrow, B.value as BOP, B.country from LendBorr L, BOPData B where (L.country = B.country) and (L.year = B.year)

%md #### ii. Net Cash Inflow from Financing Activities and Expenditure Cash Flows Next, we shall consider the **Net Cash Inflow** from [Financing Activities](http://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/cashflowfromfinancing.asp?layout=infini&v=5E&orig=1&adtest=5E). Financing activities include receiving cash from issuing stock and issuing bonds. Shown on the left(below), is a bar

chart to demonstrate the cash inflow. We can observe that Bolivia at one time had the highest cash inflow from financing activities which became negative within three years.

On the other hand, Brazil has shown impressive growth in terms of the cash inflow, staying constant over time and rising over the recent years while Paraguay's cash inflows

have been increasing only recently, from negative to largely positive in four years. Although, presently Brazil is performing good, chances are that it would be

overtaken by its neighbours Uruguay and Paraguay in the years to come.
Financial activities form a large part of the economy, and as such cash inflows should, to some extent, be responsible for the cash surplus of a country. However,
in the case of Latin America we see a different picture. The net cash inflows negatively correlate with the cash surplus values which means that with the increase
in the net cash inflows there is no increase in the cash surplus values. We consider another factor **Expenditure Cash Flows** and examine its effect on the cash
surplus values. To do so, we run a linear regression model on the cash surplus/deficit values with the cash inflow and expenditure cash flow values as the
features. The expenditure cash flow feature has a larger negative weight than the cash inflow and this explains the ineffectiveness of net cash inflows. The
expenditure has a dominant effect on cash surplus/defict, with the increase in expenditure, the deficit would obviously increase and this is well confirmed by the

regression model and the scatter plot below. The deficit increases to such an extent that even with increasing cash inflow, it is not able to cope up, giving the
apparent effect that increasing cash inflows decreases surplus and consequently resulting in a negative correlation value for cash inflow.
Below the paragraph that shows the regression model, are two paragraphs that demonstrate the regression results visually. The negative correlation can easily been
seen. As far as Paraguay is concerned, it has had the least expenditure cash flows among all the nations of the region as compared to Uruguay and Brazil which have
had the greatest expenditures. By the results of the regression model, it would also have the least deficit or more surplus and this is what we get to see in the
scatter plots, Bolivia and Paraguay lead the other countries in terms of cash surplus while Brazil has the lowest cash surplus because of the high value of expenditures.

Financial activities form a large part of the economy, and as such cash inflows should, to some extent, be responsible for the cash surplus of a country. However,

in the case of Latin America we see a different picture. The net cash inflows negatively correlate with the cash surplus values which means that with the increase

in the net cash inflows there is no increase in the cash surplus values. We consider another factor Expenditure Cash Flows and examine its effect on the cash

surplus values. To do so, we run a linear regression model on the cash surplus/deficit values with the cash inflow and expenditure cash flow values as the

features. The expenditure cash flow feature has a larger negative weight than the cash inflow and this explains the ineffectiveness of net cash inflows. The

expenditure has a dominant effect on cash surplus/defict, with the increase in expenditure, the deficit would obviously increase and this is well confirmed by the

regression model and the scatter plot below. The deficit increases to such an extent that even with increasing cash inflow, it is not able to cope up, giving the

apparent effect that increasing cash inflows decreases surplus and consequently resulting in a negative correlation value for cash inflow.



Below the paragraph that shows the regression model, are two paragraphs that demonstrate the regression results visually. The negative correlation can easily been

seen. As far as Paraguay is concerned, it has had the least expenditure cash flows among all the nations of the region as compared to Uruguay and Brazil which have

had the greatest expenditures. By the results of the regression model, it would also have the least deficit or more surplus and this is what we get to see in the

scatter plots, Bolivia and Paraguay lead the other countries in terms of cash surplus while Brazil has the lowest cash surplus because of the high value of expenditures.

paragraphs.title: Net Cash Inflow from Financing Activities(% of GDP)
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select * from CashFData

//perform multivariate regression using Cash Surplus/Deficit data and the cash inflow from financing activities and expenditure cash flows
import org.apache.spark.mllib.linalg.Vectors
import org.apache.spark.mllib.feature.StandardScaler
import org.apache.spark.mllib.regression.LabeledPoint
import org.apache.spark.mllib.regression.{LinearRegressionWithSGD, LinearRegressionModel}

val ordCashF = cashFData.orderBy("country", "year").select("value")                             //first order the values by the country and year
val ordCashS = cashSData.orderBy("country", "year").select("value")
val ordCashE = cashEData.orderBy("country", "year").select("value")

val finance = ordCashF.map(row => row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)                          //get the cash inflow from finance values
val expense = ordCashE.map(row => row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)                          //get the expenditure cash flow values
val surplus = ordCashS.map(row => row.getAs[String]("value").toDouble)                          //get the cash surplus/deficit values

val surExp = surplus.zip(expense)                                                               //get the key value pairs for surplus-expense    
val surFin = surplus.zip(finance)                                                               //get the key value pairs for surplus-finance

val features = surExp.cogroup(surFin)                                                           //get the features by grouping the previous rdds
val trainingData = features.map(ele => LabeledPoint(ele._1, Vectors.dense(ele._2._1.iterator.next, ele._2._2.iterator.next)))

val scaler = new StandardScaler(withMean = true, withStd = true).fit(trainingData.map(ele => ele.features))     //scaler model to perform scaling
val trainingSet = trainingData.map(ele => LabeledPoint(ele.label, scaler.transform(ele.features))).cache()      //the training set for regression

val model = LinearRegressionWithSGD.train(trainingSet, 50)                                      //perform regression on the data

println("The weights of the model [expense, finance] : " + model.weights)

%md #### iii. Purchasing Power Parity **Purchasing Power Parity** approximates the total adjustment that must be made on the currency exchange rates between countries that allows the exchange to be
equal to the purchasing power of each country's currency. The purchasing parity plot is shown below(on the left side).It is an important indicator of the economic
health of nations. A country with higher purchasing parity will be able to purchase more in the international market as compared to a country with less parity.
This has the following consequences, greater parity leads to less outflow of cash in paying debt and less inflow of cash in receiving money, leading to altogether
less change in the cash stock. On the other hand, less purchasing parity leads to more outflow of cash in paying debt and more inflow of cash in receiving money.
**Net changes in the stock of Cash** is the increase or decrease in cash stock or cash equivalents in a period of one year. This factor can indicate dramatic
changes in the economy of a country or region. The line graph shown below(on the right) has the cash stock change percentages on the y-axis and it indicates a lot
of change taking place over the last decade especially in the case of Uruguay, the graph goes up and down every consecutive year. Changes for Brazil have gone down
and for Paraguay and Uruguay they have gone up for the recent years.
The changes in the net change in cash stock can be explained on the basis of purchasing parity. By the explanation above, Brazil has more purchasing power parity
and so has less outflow or inflow of cash leading to a rather stable change in cash stock over the recent years. This is needed for the nation because in case of
heavy debt, less amount of money will flow out of the country; whereas the other nations such as Paraguay and Bolivia that have less purchasing parity will have
to keep debt low to prevent the outflow of large sums of cash. These other countries do have low debt but their net change in cash is still significantly positive.
Another advantage of having high purchasing parity values is that it allows for more investment in assets as is indicated by the table in the paragraphs below the
graphs, only two nations make it to the list of countries having above mean asset investment: Brazil and Argentina which are also distinctly at the top in the
purchasing power parities.

%md #### iv. Consumer Prices The last factor that we shall examine is the percentage change in consumer prices. This factor is an indicator of how stable or unstable the markets of a country
are. The bar chart shown below indicates that the consumer prices have been the most unstable for Argentina with both the highest and the lowest values occuring in

consecutive years. Others such as Brazil and Paraguay have remained largely constant with only slight variations. Consumer Price change is a factor of internal
economy which relates only to the households - increase in consumer prices will reduce the purchasing power while a decrease in prices will increase the purchasing
power. It is used as a net measure of inflation. Controlled inflation indicates healthier internal economy and more inflation indicates a less healthy economy.
Therefore, it is of utmost importance that the consumer prices be controlled and kept low although this is dependent, to some extent, on the financial institutions.

Fluctuating prices are indicative of unstability in the internal markets.

%md Apart from the analysis done in the preceding paragraphs, regional growth is likey to be negative second year in a row. Brazil, which is Paraguay's
largest trading partner is in a deep recession. Still, by the projections of the IMF, growth for Paraguay is expected to stay resilient at 3%. That
Paraguay has had debt under control is an indication of good macro-economic policies. Even the change in consumer prices has not been much although this
can be partly attributed to favourable weather conditions that have helped agriculture. The general government lending and borrowing along with controlled
expenditure cash flows have maintained stable Balance of Payments and high cash surplus. Overall, the banking system appears sound. Additionally, Paraguay
has initiated an umbrella program called 'Sowing Opportunities' aimed at poverty reduction and inclusive growth. Such policies are surely going to have a
positive impact on the economy of the country. Even the region seems to be progressing faster than before as can be inferred from the GDP growth of the region.
